description: Abanotubani is Tbilisi's historic sulfur bath district, home to natural hot springs that gave the city its name. This ancient neighborhood features Persian-inspired bathhouses with distinctive brick dome architecture, dating back to the 5th century. The therapeutic sulfur waters have been a vital social and cultural hub for over 1,500 years, serving as places not just for bathing, but for business meetings, celebrations, and matchmaking.
highlights: Natural hot springs with therapeutic sulfur water at 38-45°C (100-113°F)
Distinctive brick dome architecture that rises from the ground like molehills
Chreli-Abano (Orbeliani Baths) with stunning blue and turquoise mosaic tiles and Persian-inspired design
King Erekle's Bath - former private bathhouse of 18th century Georgian royalty
Traditional kisi scrub - vigorous exfoliation treatment with textured mitt and foam
Historic bathhouses dating to the 17th and 18th centuries
Monument depicting the legendary falcon and pheasant from the founding story
Religious diversity with Georgian, Armenian, and Catholic churches, mosque, synagogue, and Zoroastrian fire temple all in one small area
tips: Book private rooms in advance, especially during peak tourist season
Visit in the morning when water is warmest, or early evening for tranquil atmosphere
Remove all jewelry before bathing, especially silver (sulfur reacts with it)
Limit time in sulfur water to 12 minutes maximum, no more than four dips total
Bring or buy bottled water - it gets extremely hot and dehydration is a risk
Bring washcloth, soap, towel, and slippers if you have them
Get the kisi scrub treatment - it's an essential part of the authentic experience (10-20 GEL)
Public baths are gender-segregated and involve communal nudity
Water is changed once weekly (usually Sunday night), so plan accordingly
Prices: Public baths 5-10 GEL, private rooms 70-250 GEL per hour
Try Bathhouse No. 5 for best balance of price and quality
Most bathhouses located in Abanotubani district near the river and Old Meidan
vibe: Ancient and restorative with a perfect blend of social ritual and therapeutic relaxation. The steam-filled domed rooms create an otherworldly atmosphere where centuries of tradition merge with the simple pleasure of warm healing waters. It's both deeply Georgian and universally human - a place where locals and visitors alike come to shed stress, dead skin, and the barriers between strangers.
expectations: Luxurious spa experience similar to modern Western facilities
reality: Authentic, sometimes rustic bathhouses with centuries of character
Water changed weekly, not pristine but naturally therapeutic
Public baths involve communal nudity and social interaction
Cultural ritual meant for leisurely enjoyment over hours
Vigorous kisi scrub that removes layers of dead skin (can feel intense but incredibly effective)
unique_facts: The name 'Tbilisi' literally means 'warm place' from Georgian word 'tpili' - inspired by these hot springs
King Vakhtang Gorgasali discovered the springs in 5th century when his falcon (or wounded deer) fell into the hot water
At its peak in the 13th century, Tbilisi had over 65 bathhouses; today fewer than a dozen remain
Alexandre Dumas visited for over a month in 1858 and worried he'd never experience such baths in Paris again
Alexander Pushkin praised the luxury of Tbilisi's baths during his 1829 visit
Anton Chekhov was among the notable visitors to these historic baths
The baths served as matchmaking venues where future mothers-in-law would observe potential brides
The area was called 'Seidabad' in the 17th century and 'Kharpukhi' (Armenian for 'to cough') due to a healing stone that protected from illness
Sulfur waters are believed to alleviate skin conditions and reduce joint pain
The kisi scrub tradition mirrors Turkish hammam treatments but is distinctly Georgian
surprises: The iconic dome architecture isn't decorative - it allows natural light to enter and sulfuric steam to escape
You're literally bathing in the same springs that inspired the city's founding 1,500 years ago
The baths were social hubs for everything from business deals to weddings, not just hygiene
Abanotubani contains all major historical religious buildings (Georgian, Armenian, Catholic churches, mosque, synagogue, and Zoroastrian temple) in one tiny area
The water temperature stays naturally consistent at 38-45°C without modern heating systems
Public baths can cost as little as 5 GEL (about $2 USD) per hour
The Persian-inspired Orbeliani Baths look more Turkish or Iranian than Georgian, reflecting Tbilisi's position on the ancient Silk Road
Some bathhouses still operating today are 300-400 years old
The intensity of the kisi scrub reveals just how much dead skin accumulates - expect to see it rolling off in visible clumps
Despite being a top tourist attraction, locals still use these baths regularly as part of their cultural tradition
